I have a question  for everyone ... Don't ",{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"blow this out of proportion"}},"."]}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "blow this out of proportion" means to exaggerate the importance or seriousness of something beyond what is reasonable or justified. In the context of Noel's statement, he is requesting others not to make his question or its implications seem more significant or dramatic than they truly are."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are some example sentences with different meanings and contexts:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Exaggerate a Rumor:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""The rumor about Sarah switching schools isn't a big deal, but the students keep blowing it out of proportion like she's moving to another country.""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Reacting Intensely to Minor Issues:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""I know I forgot to call you back, but there's no need to blow it out of proportion. It was just a small oversight.""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Taking Constructive Criticism Poorly:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""When I mentioned that the report needed a few corrections, Jamie blew it out of proportion and acted like I was criticizing their entire work ethic.""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"6","props":{"children":"In each example, the phrase is used to convey an overreaction or unnecessary escalation of a situation."}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"Symbol(react.fragment)","key":null,"props":{"children":["Noel: I'm a sensitive guy.... I ",{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"have a crush on everyone"}},"."]}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "have a crush on everyone" in this context suggests that Noel tends to develop romantic or affectionate feelings for many people, rather than being selective or having a crush on just one person at a time. It implies a tendency to be easily attracted to different individuals."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are examples of other meanings and contexts in which the phrase "have a crush on" could be used:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Singular Attraction"}},": "]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"em","key":"0","props":{"children":"I have a crush on the new barista at the coffee shop."}}," ",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"This means the speaker is especially attracted to or interested in the new barista."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Admiration"}},":"]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"em","key":"0","props":{"children":"She has a crush on her math teacher because he's so inspiring."}},{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"In this context, it can indicate a deep admiration or fondness, without necessarily being romantic."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Temporary Infatuation"}},": "]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"em","key":"0","props":{"children":"When I was in school, I had a crush on the lead singer of the band."}},{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"Here, it suggests a fleeting or temporary admiration for someone based on limited interaction or idealized notions."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"7","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Light-hearted or Humor"}},": "]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"em","key":"0","props":{"children":"I have a crush on pizza—it always makes me happy!"}},{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"In this less serious context, it uses the phrase humorously to express a strong liking for something non-human, like food or an activity."}},"
"]}},"

"]}},"

It was more like an ",{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"power trip"}}," kind of thing."]}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "power trip" refers to a situation where someone uses their authority or influence in an exaggerated or unwarranted way, often to feel superior or boost their ego. It often has a negative connotation, implying that the person is more interested in exercising power for its own sake rather than using it responsibly or fairly."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are some example sentences that illustrate the different meanings or usages of "power trip":"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Exerting Authority"}},":"]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"The manager went on a power trip, making everyone stay late for no real reason."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Feeling Dominant"}},":"]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"He was on a power trip, barking orders at everyone just because he got promoted."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Experiencing Enjoyment in Control"}},":"]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"Some people seem to enjoy being on a power trip, not realizing how it affects others around them."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"6","props":{"children":"In each of these contexts, the focus is on the excess or misuse of authority or control, often for personal satisfaction rather than for any constructive purpose."}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"Symbol(react.fragment)","key":null,"props":{"children":["Felicity's Father: We are here because we try to understand why you are so ",{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"adamant about"}}," New York."]}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "adamant about" in this context means being very determined or insistent about New York. It implies that Felicity is firm in her opinion or desire regarding something related to New York, and she is not willing to change her stance easily."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are some example sentences demonstrating other contexts or nuances of “adamant about”:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":""Despite the heavy rain, he was adamant about going for a run.""}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"This means he was very determined to go running and wouldn’t let the rain change his decision."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":""The teacher was adamant about students handing in their assignments on time.""}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"This indicates that the teacher insisted on the importance of meeting deadlines."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":""She's adamant about not eating meat for health and ethical reasons.""}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"Here, it shows her firm and steadfast commitment to her decision not to eat meat."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"7","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":""He was adamant about the team reaching a consensus before moving forward with any plans.""}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"This suggests that he strongly insisted on the importance of achieving agreement within the team."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"in mint condition"}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "in mint condition" refers to something that is new or like new, showing no signs of wear or damage. This term is often used in the context of collectibles, antiques, or items such as books, stamps, and coins, where maintaining the original, flawless state is important."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Example Sentences:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"I found an old vinyl record from the 1970s, and it's still in mint condition."}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":"My grandfather's collection of classic cars is impressive, all are perfectly restored and in mint condition."}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":"The rare comic book was appraised at a high value because it was in mint condition."}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"6","props":{"children":"Other Meanings:
While "in mint condition" specifically implies pristine or untouched quality, the phrase doesn't typically have other meanings. However, "mint" by itself can be used as a colloquial term in British English to describe something as excellent or cool."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"8","props":{"children":"Example Sentences (using "mint" colloquially):"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"10","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"That new restaurant downtown is absolutely mint; you have to try it."}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":"Her new jacket looks mint, perfect for the upcoming winter season."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"freak out"}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "freak out" generally means to become visibly upset, anxious, or agitated, often suddenly. It's often used to describe a strong emotional reaction to something unexpected or stressful."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Example Sentences for Different Meanings:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":[{"type":"strong","key":"0","props":{"children":"Extreme Excitement:"}}," "]}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[""I freaked out when I found out we won the concert tickets!"",{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"In this context, "freak out" is used to describe an intense emotional reaction due to excitement rather than fear or anxiety."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Surprise or Shock:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[""She freaked out when she saw the surprise party all set up for her."",{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"Here, "freak out" is associated with shock and surprise, not necessarily negative."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Unexpected Development:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[""The system freaked out and crashed when we ran the new software update."",{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"In this technical context, "freak out" describes an unexpected failing or malfunction."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"7","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Cultural or Social Commentary:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[""The fashion industry will freak out when they see his revolutionary designs."",{"type":"ul","key":"1","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"Used metaphorically, "freak out" can imply a major reaction, often within a community or industry."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"6","props":{"children":"In all these examples, "freak out" indicates a strong, often sudden reaction, but the trigger and nature of that reaction can vary from negative to positive."}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"Symbol(react.fragment)","key":null,"props":{"children":["So we'll ",{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"take a rain check"}}," on that dance."]}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "take a rain check" originally comes from the practice of issuing a ticket at a rained-out event that allows you to come back at a later date. In the sentence you provided, it means postponing or rescheduling the dance for another time because the person is unable or unwilling to attend at the moment."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are a few example sentences demonstrating other meanings of the phrase:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Postponing a Meeting:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""I can't make it to the meeting today; let's take a rain check for tomorrow.""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Declining an Invitation Politely with Intent to Reschedule:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""Thanks for inviting me to dinner tonight, but I have other commitments. Can I take a rain check?""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"5","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":{"type":"strong","key":null,"props":{"children":"Delaying a Plan:"}}}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":""We were planning to go hiking this weekend, but the weather is looking bad. Let's take a rain check.""}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"6","props":{"children":"In all these examples, "take a rain check" indicates an intention to revisit or fulfill the proposal at a later time. It is generally used as a polite way to decline an invitation or delay a commitment."}},"
"]}},{"type":"StudyNote","key":null,"props":{"className":"","note":{"type":"b","key":null,"props":{"children":"Pass out"}},"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"The phrase "pass out" in the user-given sentence likely means to lose consciousness temporarily or faint. This is a common usage when someone might become dizzy or faint and momentarily loses awareness."}},"
",{"type":"p","key":"2","props":{"children":"Here are other meanings of "pass out" along with example sentences:"}},"
",{"type":"ol","key":"4","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"To distribute or hand out items to people:"}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"The teacher will pass out the tests to the students once everyone is seated."}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":"Volunteers passed out flyers during the event to inform people about the charity."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":[{"type":"p","key":"0","props":{"children":"To graduate or complete a course or training, usually in a military context (more common in British English):"}},"
",{"type":"ul","key":"2","props":{"children":["
",{"type":"li","key":"1","props":{"children":"After months of intense training, the new cadets will pass out at the ceremony next week."}},"
",{"type":"li","key":"3","props":{"children":"He was thrilled to pass out from the military academy with honors."}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}},"
"]}}]}}}}]}}
